boardgame.name: MHA Jumpchain OC - Nomu OC - Musutafu Taro "1st Contact"
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Regardless of origin, you begin "Musutafu, Japan" home city of U. A. High and the location where much of this story's events take place.

boardgame.name: Endless Legend
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Long ago, The Endless, a race of unimaginable power ruled over the galaxy, their power unrivaled. None could stand against them, so it was only fitting that they tore themselves apart from the inside out. Ages after their passing, their mark can still be seen on the galaxy, and nowhere is it stronger than one world.

Auriga.

boardgame.name: CULTivate
boardgame.description:
CULTivate is a take-that, pattern-building game from Pops & Bejou Games.

Play as a cult leader working to fill your compound with followers to help you carry out your agenda. But watch out! Rival cult leaders may try to sabotage you or convert the followers you can’t keep in line. You might also garner unwanted attention from pesky investigators who try to get in your way. Persuade the right followers, outwit your foes, and rise above the rest.

In the game CULTivate, you work to collect follower meeples needed to match the pattern of your character's agenda. Play cards from your hand allowing you to gain followers, manage follower placement within your compound, and sabotage rival cult leaders. As you draw cards, Undercover Investigations can pop up and add investigators to your compound stopping you from recruiting followers. Not gaining the type of followers you want? Make exchanges with follower meeples in the supply to help you complete your agenda and fill your compound. As you recruit followers you will activate powers making it easier for you to fill your compound. When a player fills their compound, the end of the game is triggered. Players tally the points of their followers, points from completed agendas, and any earned bonuses to see who comes out on top.

-description from publisher
boardgame.boardgamehonor: 2022 UK Games Expo Best Card Game (General) Judges Award Winner
2022 UK Games Expo Best Card Game (General) Nominee

boardgame.name: Harmonic - A Magical Weapon for Bards
boardgame.description:
"Harmonic was designed to help bards utilize their bardic abilities during melee combat. Though most bards enjoy staying out of melee action, preferring to enhance and cheer on their friends from a distance, there are those who enjoy getting into the middle of the action.

Harmonic allows bards to utilize their known spells during melee combat without using a spell slot. The drawbacks are the bard must be in melee combat, and they must successfully hit their target with the harmonic weapon. In addition, these weapons have limited charges. Using the last charge may result in the weapon vanishing from their hand during combat.

Several versions of this weapon have been created to allow bards with enough coin to purchase a greater powered Harmonic.

The pricing reflects the availability of the item. Not many bards wish to sell their harmonic weapon, and quantities are limited."

(User Summary)

boardgame.name: Tempo!
Темпо
boardgame.description:
How do you survive on a desert island? How to become a millionaire without working? In Tempo! you'll have to find answers to these and many more tricky questions and share them with your friends! But remember: you have only 1 minute and 6 words. Not challenging enough? Take a condition card from the special pile and follow the terms on it to get maximal score. For example, build the sentence using as many words starting with letter “O” as possible and mentioning one name of a sport.
To win the game, follow the conditions and make up the ideas your friends will like.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Wild Space: Encounters
Wild Space: Incontri Ravvicinati
Wildes Weltall: Aliens
boardgame.description:
Empire’s explorers have just discovered a new planet inhabited by an unknown species: highly technologically advanced Aliens, exclusively feeding on minerals.
Seize the opportunity to welcome these peaceful people in your Crew, and to benefit from their powerful skills. This will ask you to collect Quartz, those precious stones that they are fond of.

Encounters brings a new resource to Wild Space : Quartz. New Crew cards earn you some when played in front of you. And at the end of your turn, you have got the new additional option to spend Quartz, for recruiting an Alien and add it to your Crew. Aliens count as regular Crew cards but they come with powerful abilities, enhancing your combos.

Components
1 double sided Planet tile
22 Crew cards
21 Alien cards
20 Quartz plastic crystals
6 double sided Captain cards
6 solo mode cards
1 rulebook

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Korzenie Siekierek
boardgame.description:
Korzenie Siekierek is an adventure boardgame about history of Siekierki, that now are part of the Mokotów department. During the game players will meet famous people form this village and take part in important historical events.

All components including event cards and board are based on true historical information, gathered during hundreds of hours of meetings with former citizens of Siekierki.

During each of their turns, player roll 3 dices, chooses two of them and move their pawn through the types of terrain indicated by dices (fields, pawns, swamps...). When they finish their movement on certain points on the main board (the map) they can perform corresponding action. For example visiting blacksmith gives them special items, in chapel they can rest etc. Most important places are areas with crystal tokens - there players can fulfill tasks (sometimes alone, sometimes in cooperation with other players). Fulfilling tasks grants vicory points, items or bonus abilities.

First player, who completes 3 hard tasks (red ones) wins the game.

Korzenie Siekierek combines educational and historical values ​​with good fun, requiring a well-thought-out strategy, cooperation between players and a bit of luck.

Game was produced for Center of Culture "Dorożkarnia".

boardgame.name: Bao
Bao Board Game
Bao Electronic Board Game
Fun Strategy Bao Gem Game
楽しい作戦バオ宝石ゲーム
boardgame.description:
Bao Game helps in developing strategic thinking skills in an enjoyable way. The game also provides fun, enjoyment, social interactions and relaxation. It is one the most interesting, enjoyable, fascinating and challenging games. New special Learn-mode in this game makes it very easy to learn.

The game from version 2.0.1 has inbuilt “Learn” mode, available by selecting Menu > Preferences > Level > Learn. Available moves are highlighted in pink for user to choose from and play.

boardgame.name: Le Jeu du Potager
boardgame.description:
In this game inspired by the French equivalent to Snakes & Ladders ("jeu de l'oie"), curious youngsters will learn how to grow plants. Weather effects are accounted for and players will have to take care of their vegetable patch through their progression in the game.
This is an educative game for young kids.

Description from the French editor website:

"À vos graines, prêts, plantez !

Prendre soin de son potager au fil des saisons pour récolter les plus beaux légumes ?

C’est facile avec le jeu du potager ! Dans ce jeu de plateau, les joueurs doivent faire pousser leurs légumes en évitant les embûches pour devenir de vrais jardiniers en herbe. Le jeu idéal pour petits et grands afin de découvrir de manière ludique les secrets du potager au naturel."

Box contents:
1 board
98 cards
6 wooden pawns
1 wooden die
1 rulebook

Players take turns rolling a die to progress on the board. Each progress will grant them access to a card (weather/animals/bonus) helping them towards or impeding the growing of their vegetable garden. The game ends whenver a player reaches the end. The player with the most beautiful vegetable patch (most points) wins.

boardgame.name: Samoorganizujmy się!
boardgame.description:
In XIX-th and at the beginning of XX-th century in many places in Poland people decided to set up cooperatives. Some of them gathered farmers, others bakers, milkmen and weavers or gathered people of different jobs.

In Samoorganizujmy się players set up their own cooperatives, employ workers, build common buildings, meet famous social activists and participate in bigger projects, that onvolve many cooperatives.

All cards contain historical photos and illustrations and most of them show real historical people, places, institutions or projects. Game gives players not only fun, but also real historical knowledge about history of cooperativity in Poland.

In each turn players simultaneously play one card from their hand and add it to their tableau, finally they pass all cards remaining in their hand to the player on their left. Blue and red cards improve their production (which allows them to play more expensive cards), green cards raise morale of their cooperativity, pink cards allow cooperation between players and yellow provide instant actions.

At the end of each round (after seventh card being played) player with most cards with their arms and player with highest morale - get victory point. At the end of the game players resolve all cards with "End of the Game" effects and score for them. Player with most victory points, wins the whole game.

Game was produced for Fundacja Wspomagania Wsi (Rural Development Fundation) to promote their projects and to develop historical knowledge in small towns.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: We're Doomed!: Unspeakable Treachery Promo Card
boardgame.description:
It's a secret event on the player that draws it. Shuffle the card with the other event cards during set up.

Card was a reward during the Game Boy Geek Kickstarter Season 8 in 2020

listing.notes:
NEW! Boy Game Geek Promo
+Shipping
PayPal and Venmo payment preferred.

boardgame.name: The Crown of Leaves
boardgame.description:
Hybrid visual novel and point and click adventure. You play a failed jeweler that must return to his home country and start over.

User Summary

boardgame.name: The Choice of Life: Middle Ages
boardgame.description:
Card-based life simulation set in the Middle Ages.

User Summary

boardgame.name: Clock Strike Zero
boardgame.description:
From the publishers blurb:

Join a cast of ambitious, fledgling adventurers as they stop if in the bucolic backwater of Blackwyrm on the road to the capital of Herlivik. Intending to make a quick stop to rest at the local inn before resuming their journey, the intrepid travelers realize that things are not what they seem in this odd little town, and their pit stop spirals into a full-blown adventure as they're drawn in to investigate a growing peril threatening Blackwyrm's people.
boardgame.rpg: Old School Reference and Index Compilation (OSRIC)

boardgame.name: Fortune & Famine
boardgame.description:
Fortune & Famine is a strategy card game, set in medieval times of magic. You play as the ruler of a growing kingdom, attempting to store more grain in 12 rounds than opposing rulers. To do that, you will spend silver to bid against other rulers on worker cards which produce unique goods or services for your kingdom. You will need to balance your silver and grain economies, and take some risks. The primary risk-reward comes in the form of FAMINE cards, which show up with increasing regularity as the game progresses. You can store as much of your grain as you wish to safety for a single silver coin. This makes it economically beneficial to leave your grain growing as long as possible. But beware! When FAMINE strikes, you will lose half of it!

Variable player powers are built in with six rulers. Each ruler gives a unique power to their kingdom. Rulers can be distributed randomly at the start or chosen by each player for the cost of less starting silver.

If all else fails and you think an opposing ruler is running away with the game, you may be able to slow them with judiciously played evil wizard cards, although each wizard will cost a precious spot in your kingdom!

-description from designer

boardgame.name: One Million Hungry Kisses
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The world is over. Everything is nanobots. Everything, sky or wind or dirt, is all gray. Everything but The Cutie.

This is a 3-9 players romance game where one player is "The Cutie," the last human survivor, and the rest of the players play Gray Goo in "The Hive" that has devoured the earth. And you spin the bottle!

CONTENT WARNING: Vore, Imbalanced Power Dynamic of Many VS One

boardgame.name: Angola 1987-1988
Angola 1988: End of the Cold War in Africa
boardgame.description:
Angola 1988 simulates the operations led between July 1987 and July 1988 between the Angolan government forces, supported by the Cubans, and the
UNITA, supported by the South African armed forces.
This period marks the final “round” of the Cold War before the fall of the Soviet Union in August 1991.

One player controls the government camp, composed of three factions: MPLA (and the FAPLA armed forces), SWAPO and Cuban forces (CUBA).
The anti-government camp controls three factions : FLEC/FNLA, UNITA and the South African forces (SADF).

Difficulty : 6 / 10
Solo-playability : 4 / 10
Duration : 3 - 4 hours
One turn : 1 month
Scale : liaison between two zones : 200 - 400 km.
Each ground unit represents 1,000 to 5,000 troops. Air units represents 10-20 aircraft.
Units : 1 counter = 1 brigade or 1 battalion of 250 - 2500 men


Vae Victis magazine #154 January-February 2021.

boardgame.name: Wandering Monster
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

As a prestigious academic known for your work on many bestiaries, you have kept from the world a terrible secret: you like to fuck monsters. But that isn't all.

You have traveled to other countries (all part of the so-called "Monster Bloc"), using your encyclopedic knowledge of non-human cultures and customs to engage in sexual relations with creatures of all kinds (an obvious taboo), all of which were—under your home country's laws—below the legal age of consent, 18 (something most would describe as a grotesque, if not technically illegal, act).

The tattered map you keep by your side while journeying has no place names. Instead, each kingdom, empire, and republic is denoted only by a single number: the age of consent within its borders.

This is the story of your travels, your There and Back Again. Though dragonfire and burglary probably aren't in your future, urethral burn and stolen kisses might be.

boardgame.name: ♡Making Love♡
boardgame.description:
New Desire for 2 Queers

Publisher's blurb:

In ♡Making Love♡, you maybe have sex at the end. Like, as a person in real life. These are the instructions for how to do that. Because like, you don't always wanna just go up to a stranger and fuck them. But also like, it's fun to shake things up. And restrictions breed creativity! These are just pages of restrictions!

We gotta talk about some content warnings though. This game talks about kissing, and other people. It even calls out that there are those who would pressure someone into an intimate space when using this game. It's also got a very conversational tone, and the game is encouraging you to form a romantic or sexual moment. There's some nudity involved, and lot of touching. And it has a bunch of eye contact, too.

This game is about meeting another person and getting to know them, and also getting to know yourself. This game is about communication and pleasure and safety and discovery.

boardgame.name: Fortress On The Goblin Sea
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A big dungeon. Lots of art. 29 pages+

boardgame.name: Temple of the Bastard Elves (And Other Outstanding Issues)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A dungeon for your players to explore: the Temple of the Bastard Elves.

A guide to creating “typical” simple dungeons in Broceliande—that is, dungeons matching the kinds of ruins parties will most often run across, organized by the main architect cultures in the area (dwarves and goblins, plus humans and elves of the three known eras) and by who occupies the structure dungeon now.

Points of interest in the Broceliandaise baronies, including Pont-L’évêque (populated mostly by elves and home to a powerful bishop), Livarot (a once-elven land now contested by the orc knights of Lord Draa) and Eese (a barony on the edge of the human Empire of the Hunger Kings, mostly wild). Plus a d100 table of wardogs.

boardgame.name: Heroes of Thargos: The Cursed Empire Card Game
boardgame.description:
In the Cursed Empire Heroes of Thargos Card Game, players battle one another or collaborate in the RPG setting of Thargos using a simple-to-learn card-resource management system to compete over four mission tracks. Each track has a mission card for players to fulfill, for which they will receive victory points (VP); as mission cards are completed, you replace them from your own decks to help even the playing field.

The Additional Story Mode which can be played from the base set and using expansions too will allow for collaborative play and street level adventures that can be a tie-in for the Cursed Empire RPG for side quests or build on the standalone card game from the Core Set I.

Solo Play is also an option using the Core Set I.

You can construct a deck to match your own playing style, using the components of the base game and card pack releases. Each character card has a "character point" value, which indicates both the power level of the character and the number of VPs required to win your match. The stronger your deck, the more VP you need. For clarity the Core Set has a great deal of replay-ability and you do not need additional packs to play multiple games. you can play out of the box without any prior deck construction as there are deck lists to get you started.

The two-player Core Set I box of Heroes of Thargos Cursed Empire Card Game contains 136 cards with which players can build their starting decks:


16 unique Character Cards comprising key character types such as The Crimson Knight, Spider Darkun/Slayer, Cobra Sorceress, Kurnor Assassin and Karg Demon Summoner.



40 Mission Cards (18 pairs of specific missions, 4 individual missions), all set in the World of Thargos.



40 Lasting Cards (15 pairs of specific cards, 10 individual cards), comprising Thargos minions, objects, weapons etc.



40 Action Cards (15 pairs of specific actions, 10 individual actions), comprising a host of Thargos creatures and player driven events.


Two legal decks can be created from one Core Set I, although you would need additional Core Sets to create more specialized decks that use the maximum number allowed of some cards.

boardgame.name: Dimensional Criminals
boardgame.description:
Steal a rare and valuable car while jumping through different realities. Do you need a tool you don't have? Change dimensions. Are the cops on your tail? Change dimensions. Did you jump your car off a ramp but now there's a helicopter directly in your way? Change dimensions.

But watch out. Each time you change dimensions, there's a chance that the dimensional authorities will catch up with you. Keep one step ahead (or ideally, several steps ahead) and finish this one last job. Because there's always one last job.

-from publisher's Patreon page

boardgame.name: Screaming Lake
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A very LotFP 17th century one-shot (?) adventure.

boardgame.name: The Halfling City
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This installment of Cube World is all about The Halfling City which, for the time being, has no other name.

Settled within the Elven territory of Broceliande on the Hogspot river, it is a place of friendly domes, pools of syrup, frighteningly vigorous food-fights, and constant competition.

Being quite comfortable with most forms of commercial relation, and eager to delegate tasks which might require violence or plausible deniability (including but not limited to: foiling rivals, escorting trade goods, eliminating creatures that prey on shipping and locating lost or coveted valuables behind doors which might be variously locked, trapped, guarded, or all three) to freelancers, urban halflings are great patrons of the adventuring classes. It is, therefore a good place for PCs who like to keep busy.

This pdf includes:
-Notes on the city in general, including the Halflings' contest to name it
-An encounter table and guide to the major commercial houses
-An adventure-generator for PCs seeking work in the city
-Notes on the syrup-eating cyclops, a terrifying problem for which the City has yet to find a solution

boardgame.name: >No Love's Land
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

>DESIGNED FOR WAR

>YOU ARE ON OPPOSITE SIDES

>YOU HAVE FALLEN IN LOVE

You are a killer robot stationed on the moon of Ahava, covered in a dense radiation field. The only way you have to get a message to your secret girlfriend and fellow killer robot is to send them a message inscribed on a missile. Time to fire...

>LOVE CONQUERS ALL

>AND YOU WERE MADE TO CONQUER

boardgame.name: The Barony That Has The Temple that Has The Room That Has The Toad Demons
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Bad monsters are in a room. It’s a pretty good room, as fantasy adventure module rooms go, and presents some interesting problems.

The room’s in a Toad Temple, which has some cultists--before they get to the room with the monsters, your players may have to fight them, too, or maybe just sneak past. If I knew already, your game would be pretty boring.

Around the temple is the idyllic and rambling rural Broceliandaise barony of Gruyère de Comté whose distinctive features include:

-The lovely convent of Tittivila (or Tittivila, or Tittivilla) a goddess of all flesh to whom misspellings are sacred and one of the top two most popular deities in Broceliande. Although most of the nuns are just 0-levels who pray and read books on how to breed weird livestock all day, if you’re running a campaign in Broceliande, genuine fighting clerics of Tittivila will be pretty thick on the ground, so I’ve given some information about them, including a random table at the back.
-The alchemists of Gruyère de Comté, who are some of the few folks from whom your lazy Skyrim-addict player’s PC can just “buy potions” in Broceliande.
-The Festival of Japes, a happy festival, for those who seek amusement or exotic cuisine
-Skopje, a village with a delightful secret
-and a bunch of chaos-worshipping creatures bent on destroying everything in the first three bullet points

boardgame.name: Meat On The Table
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

So, if you're like me, you're sick of rolling random wilderness encounters in a sandbox campaign and then it just says like "57-Ghost" or "34-Venomous snake" and then I'm like "Fuck who wrote this table?" and then having to be like "Oh right, I did".

So I wrote a whooooooole big table of wilderness encounters with

100 Civilian encounters, like:
90 Halfling(s) moving to a new home in The Halfling City, or one of the Pudding Coasts (d4).
91 Halfling(s) moving to a new home in elven, human, or dwarven lands (d4).
92 Halfling(s) on so many drugs just vibing.

100 Dubious travelers, like:
265-266 Lone wererat disguised as (roll on Civilian table), it will be moving in the same direction as the party and share the journey with them, waiting for an ideal time to call in d4 compatriots, steal something valuable, cut their throats, and sneak off.
267 Wererats in their half-rat form (d6+1), chewing on dead horses just off the road.
268 Tracks enlarge and change from rat to human, leading to a wererat den beneath a bridge or in a ruin (2d6 wererats).

100 Military encounters, like:
309 Gnoll hunting party—clan out looking for big game or fast-moving enemies. 3d6+2 gnolls all mounted on giant boars, gnoll chief hunter, also mounted, with vulture or eagle.
310 Gnoll hunting party taking prey—as Hunting Party above. Taking: 1-7 Herd of deer, 8-11 sheep and goats, 12-17 wild horses, 18-19 giant monster, 20 unicorn.
100 Goblin encounters, like:

521 Goblins smacking farm animals (d6).
522 Goblin scouts “surveying” (pointing to random landscape features, holding a telescope) (d6).
523 Goblins carrying off a random hogtied NPC (roll d100 on Civilians table) (d6).
524 Goblins teasing local children (d6).

Plus bandits and weird wildlife and more...
And if you're like "Oh what's a cannibal mermaid though?" so I also did a bestiary. It's still growing but it has all the monsters from these tables in them.

And I also wrote a bounty-hunting adventure to go with them, with a spooky swamp and a vampire.

boardgame.name: The Teratocracies
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Q: Forty-two pages! Fuck.
A: Yeah.

Q: What, pray tell, are The Teratocracies?
A: They are the scattered settlements, throughout Broceliande, ruled by monsters, by
beasts, by tyrant mutant-lords and their followers.

Q: Well that sounds like a standard pulp fantasy trope.
A: Yup. That’s why I thought maybe people might want this toy to play with even if they
weren’t running games in the chivalrous, fae-haunted wilds of Broceliande.

Q: And where are The Teratocracies?
A: They are in randomly-generated locations outside the civilized areas, so that
adventuring parties can stumble upon them or be sent to find them.

Q: How does it work?
A: Well first you randomly generate a map location for the settlement the monster runs, then you randomly generate a headquarters from which the teratocrat rules, then you roll a thrall population--the kinds of creatures the monster has charmed or enslaved...got all that so far?

Q : Yes I do.
A: Well then you roll up some other creatures on the Troublemakers table that are elsewhere in Broceliande that are connected to the settlement, then you see how big the settlement is and then you roll on a big table saying who the Teratocrat is (like: what monster) and what’s special about them and who helps them be monstrous.

Q: Are there other resources I can use here?
A: Funny you should ask, yes there are. There’s a d1000 Things About Villains table which is mostly mutations but also other things that make villains stand out, there’s a Troublemakers table which is good for generating load-bearing NPCs typical of all the areas in Broceliande and there are town and ruin generators at the end there.

Q: Can you do other things with the tables?
A: Yeah, you could make a big monster army with it, by rolling more times on the Advisors and Enforcers columns, and rolling more on the Things About Villains table for each unit. You’d use the Advisors as lieutenants. You could even build two teratocracies, roll d20 enforcers for each side and play a little wargame with a friend.

Q:I rolled up a Teratocracy and I don’t like it.
A: Roll another one.

Q: Oh this one is cool I like it.
A: See? Wasn’t that fun?

boardgame.name: Pool of Blood
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This adventure takes place deep within the deserts of the Scorpion Lands, in the Valley of Nas Akhu Khan, within Syrinx, the former empire of the Necropharoah, now infested with vile jackalmen.

The area explored is the Bastion of the Second Soul of Kheftiu Asar Butchiu, an underground temple which is—wouldn’t you know it?—rumored to contain vast wealth.

It’s a small dungeon suitable for a night or three of play and the main issue is getting out. Leaving requires three keys and finding them all requires thoroughly exploring the dungeon.

boardgame.name: The Unseelie Lands
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This installment of Cube World is a sandbox depicting the Unseelie Lands of Tomme de Savoie, where the witch-queen Nyctalis reigns. It is located within the larger continent of Broceliande--a place of faction, chivalry, and enchanted glades.

Tomme de Savoie is, for most characters, behind enemy lines. The forest is, itself, evil. The creatures in it are evil, the animals are evil, even the plants are evil.

A sandbox adventure--where characters choose objectives and roam as they see fit--is a different affair in such a place. It will not be easy to acquire provisions, equipment, arms and armor or a safe place to sleep. So, as the GM, remember to reward players with lots of treasure to keep the ratio of risk to reward reasonable.

12 pages plus Treasure Tables and Bestiary

boardgame.name: The Electric Team
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

One hundred years ago the war between magic and super-science shattered the world. Now the people are scattered across the wastelands, living in fear of monsters, mutants, tyrants, terrorists, demons, and demigods. The forces of evil rule the land, and only a small band of heroes can set things right.

This mini-setting includes six character backgrounds for use with the Troika! game system, including the Ghost Wizard, the Adolescent Plant, the Unicorn Adoptee, and the Reformed Space Tyrant. Also included are six monsters--like the Mechaminotaur, the Snake Sorcerer, and the Vegetroid--and a short history of the Great War.

boardgame.name: Black Spear: Bucolic Fantasy Role Play
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Welcome to Black Spear, dangerous adventure in an enigmatic, ancient world. Black Spear has taken the core of Openquest, pared it down for the sake of simplicity, and added modern table-top gaming philosophy to create compelling, snappy updates to the D100 system suitable for the intended themes of the game.

Black Spear aspires to accomplish rapid, deadly combat, compelling roleplay, and an overall free and simple manner of play using underutilized themes and set-pieces. It identifies as seeking to hold up the OSR way of things. The world is young, mysterious, with the unknown lying just beyond the pastures. Times are changing- can the people of the Marchlands survive these dark times?

boardgame.name: Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 0: Marchlands Setting Primer
Marchlands Setting Primer (OpenQuest)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Some might call the Marchlands a feral wilderness. Barbarian territory, unexplored, untamed, uncivilized, and inhabited by outlaws, exiles, and savages. Such people might be correct, in some ways, but the vast Marchlands are far from empty or lacking in history or culture. The people of the Marchlands live in roaming bands or pastoral clan communities. Historically, the people that are now Marchlanders came from all directions, settling in waves from the surrounding regions, sometimes from far beyond what is now regarded as the known world: refugees from the frigid wastes of the far north, exiles from a once-young empire to the south, pioneers from the lands beyond the eastern nomad ranges, and most recently those fleeing the newfound tyranny in the west. Despite their varied origins, however, the Marchlanders have come to have a distinct and identifiable culture of their own, which serves as a unifying force among the many communities. Where many Marchlander communities feud and ordinarily refuse to cooperate within this culture, the Marchlanders tend to favor their own over outsiders, and can typically set aside their grievances to address any such threats or issues.

It is in this region in increasingly strange and changing times that the Marchland Pocket Adventures take place. This document serves as a guide for the culture, factions, laws, and other information relevant to those adventures. It will be updated as that series develops. The first such adventure will be released a dew days after the initial day of release of this primer.

Marchlands Setting Primer (5E)

boardgame.name: First Season in the Marchlands: Adventure Compilation
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

An adventure compilation set in the Marchlands- a clannic, pastoral region beset by monstrosities, corruption, and banditry.

Includes the following:

Marchlands Setting Primer: A primer for the communities, culture, laws, and woes of the Marchlands

Old Lost Fort: An adventure to help an all but extinct community reclaim a lost fort from bandits, and other misadventures that ensue after, including a rat problem, a feisty band of goblins, and a minotaur at the gates.

Cattle Raid on the Marches: Raiding is a way of life, and an opportunity is given to participate in a legally sanctioned raid for cattle and riches.

A Gnawing Problem: Monstrous rodents plague the fields, and mist be found and culled if the winter is to be survived.

Dragon’s Dilemma: Farmers do not care for lost cattle, and a hungry dragon means many a lost cow. It must be stopped- but how, and at what cost?

boardgame.name: Blackacre Orchard (OpenQuest)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 4: Blackacre Orchard
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

An estate improperly acquired, an orchard besieged by vengeful spirits and decay, a labrynth of trees and a haunted house. Blackacre Orchard was once the producer of the finest apples and cider in the Marches, but no longer- now it lay abandoned, with foul beings prowling its tree rows and manor halls.

The estate much be purged of such evils, or the evils appeased with the life of the one who wronged them, if the cider is the flow freely once more. Whether the new owner, Tostein, or the widow of the prior owner, Amalia, survives the night depends on the actions of the player Character, but either way a warm cup of cider awaits them once the job is done.

boardgame.name: Blackacre Orchard (Black Spear)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 5: Blackacre Orchard
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

An estate improperly acquired, an orchard besieged by vengeful spirits and decay, a labrynth of trees and a haunted house. boardgame.name: Dragon's Dilemma (Black Spear)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 4: Dragon's Dilemma
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In a land of herd and pasture, where wealth is measured by their livestock, anything that threatens those numbers is a problem to be solved. The Herding Tribe has a dragon problem. The beast was first sighted some years ago, even then fully grown and fearsome. For a time there was no incident, but then the cattle began to vanish, followed by a sighting of the creature flying away, cow in claw. Now she takes cattle almost daily. Something must be done, though what exactly may depend on what a party is capable of achieving, and what they can do while managing to sleep at night afterward. Tracking the creature is only half the battle, after all.

boardgame.name: Dragon's Dilemma (OpenQuest)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 5: Dragon's Dilemma
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

boardgame.name: Night Café
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

“In my picture of the ‘Night Café’ I have tried to express the idea that the café is a place where one can ruin oneself, go mad or commit a crime.”

-Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh


“…one of the ugliest pictures I have done…”

-Also Vincent van Gogh, on ‘Night Café’


Night Café is a GM-less tabletop roleplaying game for 5 players where you guide the actions of the patrons of a café like the one described by Vincent van Gogh in his painting. Players will have a main playbook representing one of the aspects of the setting, but will portray multiple characters including the patrons themselves. The setting elements, the patrons and the obstacles they struggle with are generated by the players over the course of play. Night Café is inspired by games of belonging outside belonging and the principles of Powered by the Apocalypse. To play you need this zine, a single six-sided die, some index cards or scrap paper, a good amount of coins or beads, a few pens or pencils, and a single paintbrush.

This game touches on issues of mental illness, addiction, self-harm, and violence.

boardgame.name: A Gnawing Problem (5E)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 3: A Gnawing Problem
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In a land of pasture, the Field Tribe reigns supreme in working the soil for food and commodities. For better or worse, it is on their farm fields tha ttney have hedged their future- but that future is threatened. Rats of unusual size plague their fields, stripping them bare, depriving the people of their food stores and trade goods for the coming year. There is too much work to be done- someone must deal with the rat nests, but there are too few hands to work the fields, keep the watch, and eradicate the creatures.

Whether qualified or not, they will take on any hired hands that promise to help. They know the beasts are in a cave nearby, one must only find it, and deal with the dangers within. The future of the tribe may well depend on it.

boardgame.name: A Gnawing Problem (OpenQuest)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 3: A Gnawing Problem
boardgame.description:

boardgame.name: Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 2: The Old Lost Fort
The Old Lost Fort (Black Spear)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Marchlands are a harsh place, and the safe refuges of civilization far between and often mistrusting of strangers. But among the remnants of the Lost Tribe, one always has a place they can call home, and perhaps something new can arise from their ashes. Old Lost Fort includes:

Last Refuge of the Lost Tribe
The Old Lost Fort and quest to clear out the highwaymen that have occupied it
The Rats Among Us miniquest
Trolls in the Shadows miniquest
Minotaur at the Gates miniquest

boardgame.name: Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 2: The Old Lost Fort
The Old Lost Fort (OpenQuest)

boardgame.name: Cattle Raid on the Marches (5E)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 1: Cattle Raid on the Marches
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Raids are a way of life in the Marchlands, and while those on the receiving end do not appreciate the, they accept them for what they are, and at the end of a losiing raid simply rest assured that next time they will reclaim what was taken and then some. So long as the laws are abided by and no unnecessary carnage ensures, the ill feelings are kept to a minimum and life goes on.

To be given the chance to carry out a raid is one of great honor- and one with potentially lucrative results for the careful and skilled.

Concinve the members of this village that you are worth the risk, and make off with a small fortune in livestock. Make your mark on the Marchlands!

boardgame.name: Cattle Raid on the Marches (Black Spear)
Marchlands Pocket Adventures Volume 1: Cattle Raid on the Marches

boardgame.name: Super Polio: con las Calles de Caracas
boardgame.description:
A Monopoly-like game.

Become the richest player in Caracas through the purchase, rental and sale of properties.

boardgame.name: Flick of Faith: Apokaschnipse
Flick of Faith: Cataclysm
Golpe de Fe: Cataclismo
Palec boży: Kataklizm
boardgame.description:
The great noise, bright flashes, powerful eruptions! Is it the end of the world?
No, it’s just struggling gods trying to win a bet in the Archipelago of the Navel of the World!
You can't make an omelet without breaking a few eggs, right?
Things have been getting serious since the Mayan contender joined the bet. Flick your loyal Shamans right into the mess to convince the unconvinced!
Use every tricky cataclysm to help your Prophets defeat others and proof that YOU are the best among the gods!

This Expansion adds a new mechanisms - Cataclysms and Shamans, 5th player mode as well as brand new gods and Law cards you can mix with the core box!

—description from the designer
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Flick of Faith: Cthulhu God Promo

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

listing.notes:
Flick of Faith: Cataclysm This is the expansion to Flick of Faith, base game is required to play. Introducing new Mystic and Cataclysm cards to the game 2 new playable South America gods. All new Law Cards and player disk.
Buyer pays shipping. Shipping is through USPS.

boardgame.name: Monopolio... de las calles de Caracas
boardgame.description:
Become the richest player in Caracas through the purchase, rental and sale of properties.

Around the board the properties are:

Start in purple with San Agustín del Sur and urbanización El Conde, followed in sky blue by Avenida Atlántico, Plaza Catia and Avenida Sucre.
In violet Los Chaguaramos, Santa Mónica, Bello Monte and in yellow-ocre Avenida Victoria, Avenida Roosevelt and Avenida Nueva Granada.
In red, Avenida La Paz, Urbanización El Paraíso and Avenida San Martín, in yellow Avenida Andrés Bello, Parque Los Caobos and Plaza Venezuela.
In green: Sabana Grande , Francisco de avenida Miranda and Plaza Altamira and finally in royal blue, avenida Urdaneta, Avenida Bolívar.


Includes:
Board,
regulations,
a dice,
4 pawns of different colors,
32 houses and 12 hotels to build,
2 sets of cards for the Chance box and Communal Ark,
a sheet with property titles and banknotes.

boardgame.name: Kooba
boardgame.description:
Kooba is a revolutionary new targetgame that performs like a sport challenge. Every game, every round your skills are tested in the pursuit of the perfect KOOBA shot!

A Kooba game has 4 main components. 3 darts called Aeros that somewhat resemble fidget spinners, 5 round discs that magnetically attach to the gameboard, 2 sticks, and the game board itself.

The Aeros have a large hole in the center. The two sticks are stuck through this hole and made to form an X. The shot is then taken by quickly pulling apart your hands so that the Aero is forced to fly forward. Depending on where you land on the board you can score or knock your opponents back.

The game is won by scoring enough times to advance your marker to the end of it's track and then tagging the KOOBA in the center.

boardgame.name: Balance the Baker
boardgame.description: Take turns piling on the pastries but don't let the baker drop it all or you lose. 1+ players. Includes wooden baker, 6 pie pieces, 4 cake pieces, and 3 croissant pieces.

boardgame.name: Oshigatari
boardgame.description: Social deduction game where some players describe their favorite thing and one tries to hide their favorite. A topic is selected and hidden role cards distributed. One player will be the 'know-it-all' who deliberately chooses not to go with their favorite thing, but in a convincing way. The other players do describe their favorite things. After a chance for questions all players simultaneously point to who they think was the know-it-all.

boardgame.name: They Came at Night
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

They Came at Night is a twist on the classic medieval fantasy adventure. The party and several dozen townsfolk are abducted in their sleep by aliens. The aliens intend to take the characters back to their home world (for reasons which are revealed during the adventure), but their ship crashes on a harsh, uncharted planet. The players must draw on all their skill and cunning to guide their characters through a world unlike any they've seen before. Limited resources and unforgiving surroundings make for a unique challenge. Worst of all, the players are cut off entirely from their gods.

They Came at Night is a hex crawl on an alien planet. The main story line is bolstered by strange random encounters and side quests from the other survivors.

They Came at Night Includes:

Dozens of 5e encounters
Sci-fi items and gear
New 5e monsters
Printable hex map for the players to chart their exploration

boardgame.name: Flying & Creeping Creatures of Planet Archipelago
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A collection of bugs that can swarm the player characters and creatures that can swoop down out of the sky and carry away a hapless traveler. A good suppliment for any game-master.
boardgame.rpg: Planet Archipelago: A Medieval Science Fiction Role-Play Game

boardgame.name: Alien Town at Deep Port in the Falcon Empire
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A 43 page supplement with details about "alien town" The part of the Deep Port set aside for those who are not citizens of the Falcon Empire. this more detailed look at the city has several adventure starters that a game-master may use to draw the player characters into a new adventure.
boardgame.rpg: Planet Archipelago: A Medieval Science Fiction Role-Play Game

boardgame.name: IT Startup: Backend Developers do Frontend Promo Card
boardgame.description:
Kickstarter Exclusive "Backend Developers do Frontend" card for IT Startup. This action card can be added to the base game.

Card text:
"You get (1) project point for every developer you control. Every PM and Agile Coach in play gets (1) burnout point."

boardgame.name: IT Startup: Binary dice
boardgame.description: A binary dice to replace the standard dice.

boardgame.name: The Laboratory of Melifex the Mad
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Adventure Module MX-01

An adventure for level 2 characters

The city of Pinecliffe has tolerated the presence of Melifex the Mage for years, but his corruption and increasingly unusual experiments eventually had him driven out of town and to a secluded tower on the ridge overlooking the city. Now, no one has heard from Melifex “the Mad” for two months, and the city is becoming worried. Did Melifex die from his corruption or has he unleashed a sinister force that could destroy the land! Answers, adventure, and priceless magical treasure await the party brave enough to find out.
boardgame.rpg: Dungeon Crawl Classics Role Playing Game

boardgame.name: The Treasure of Melifex the Mad
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Adventure Module MX-02

An adventure for level 3 characters

Your party has braved the tricks, traps, and horrors in the laboratory of Melifex the Mad and returned with his prized magical research. Unfortunately, the crafty wizard has coded all his works with a cipher, making them worthless until the cipher is found. Finding the cipher poses your greatest challenge as possessing it could be the key to unlimited magical power and riches. Then again, it may just earn you a dagger to the ribs. You may have to find the cipher just to stay alive.
boardgame.rpg: Dungeon Crawl Classics Role Playing Game

boardgame.name: According 2 Hip Hop: The Trivia Game – OG Pack #01
boardgame.description:
According 2 Hip Hop is a trivia card game where all the questions and answers come directly from the lyrics of hip hop and rap songs. Players challenge one another with questions from their hand ranging over 40 years worth of music. Players can answer, get hints, share and win points directly or indirectly. The winner has the most points at the end of the round.

Contents: 72 cards (216 questions total), rules, and box.

boardgame.name: Cults of the Blood Gods
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

When you have already experienced death, why have faith?

If you accept that you and everyone like you is cursed by God, why cling to His word?

When you return from the other side as a blood-drinking monster, what purpose serves belief?

Kindred build and are drawn to faiths for myriad reasons. The exertion of power over a flock. Satisfying their Hunger and their Beasts. Elevation of the self. Reassurance of the possibility of redemption. A grand plan they forged or that was bestowed upon them by secret masters.

While some vampire cults span the globe hiding in plain sight, others are fringe faiths with morbid practices and ancient conspiracies lasting centuries. Others such as the incestuous Clan of Death and the malignant Church of Set — arguably the largest vampire cults of all — believe in a destiny that will enable them to impose their wills on the world of the living and the dead.

Whether for power, salvation, or transcendence, all Kindred cults wallow in blood. They shed it in sacrifice, demand it of their followers, and exalt in it in unholy baptisms proclaiming their divine glories.

These cults dedicated to blood gods are among the most insidious, damning sects of Kindred, and tonight they approach their apex of power.

Cults of the Blood Gods includes:

An in-character breakdown of the rise of esoteric beliefs among the ranks of the undead and how faith drives many of the major aspects of vampire culture.
A host of religions — from historic theocracies and globe-spanning conspiracies to fringe cults and mortal beliefs arising in the modern nights — introduced for incorporation into your character backgrounds or as supporting casts and antagonist groups in your chronicles.
The history, structure, and ambitions of the Hecata, the vampire group known as the Clan of Death, as well as a chapter dedicated to playing a vampire among the Necromancers, and the rituals for their signature Discipline: Oblivion.
Guidance on how to use ecclesiastical horror and construct cults in Vampire, making them a vivid backdrop for your own stories, including new coterie styles focused on cult play.
Faith-based story hooks and a full chronicle centered on the activities of the Hecata, involving walking corpses, ghosts, ready-made characters, and the secrets of the most twisted family in the World of Darkness.
New Loresheets, Backgrounds, and Predator types for inclusion in your chronicles, encouraging player characters to engage fully with the material presented in this book.

boardgame.name: Tzoy
boardgame.description:
This game allows for 4 modes or expedition types : head-to-head, treasure hunt (co-op), treasure hunt (no teams) and solo.

Using 3 different sizes of wooden meeples, you must place them, according to the wooden die value, on one of the 6 rings of the circular board that is suspended in the center by a rope and pole.

If the board flips, you must take back all the fallen meeples.

In the head-to-head mode, the winner is the first to place all their meeples on the board without it flipping.

In the other modes, your goal is to make the most points, with each treasure tokens and meeples giving various points, while avoiding the lava sections.

boardgame.name: Paladins of the West Kingdom: Dice Tower 2021 Pack
boardgame.description:
Special Promo for backers of the 2021 Dice Tower Kickstarter contained in pack E.

All 3 Townsfolk function the same way, allowing players to spend provisions when taking an action to ignore some of the attribute requirements:

Friar = Ignore 2 Faith per 1 Provision
Financer = Ignore 2 Influence per 1 Provision
Strongman = Ignore 2 Strength per 1 Provision

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Solo Adventurer's Guide
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Have you ever imagined being able to play in a totally unique D&D world that is capable of changing or expanding on its own? Let this guide expand the limits of your imagination and discover that it is possible to play "the most popular roleplaying game in the world" without the presence of a Dungeon Master. Open your mind and be a "masterplayer". Are you brave enough to face the fate that the dice have in store for you?
...
The purpose of this guide is to present a dungeon master emulator able to simulate the responses that a DM would give to players at a traditional tabletop game and to boost your creativity, as if it were a springboard for your imagination, so that you are able to create stories, scenarios and nonplayer characters (NPCs) in a fun, random and unpredictable way.

The Solo Adventurer Guide is all a player needs to play epic D&D adventures without the presence of a Dungeon Master.

boardgame.name: Solo Adventures
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Right from the beginning, there have been rules for solo playing D&D. These rules are intentionally faster and lighter than others available in the DMs Guild.

These are not the first solo rules for Dungeons and Dragons. There have been solo play rules build into the game right from the first edition.

For a genuine DM free role-playing experience though you need some additional assistance, more than just random rooms and corridors.

These are not the only solo rules available. The granddaddy of them all is the Mythic Game Master Emulator (GME). All solo role laying games owe some small debt to Mythic’s GME. An alternative is 5E Solo Gamebooks The Solo Adventurer’s Toolbox. That gives you nearly 170 pages of rules and tables of D&D specific solo role play tools.

These rules are different but if you have the Adventurers Toolbox and you like it then you do not need this book.

The thing that makes this set of solo rules different is that I find too many tables and too many dice rolls break the suspension of disbelief. For me, the story is more important the scrolling through hundreds of pages for the right table.

boardgame.name: MUNE: The Madey Upy Namey Emulator
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

I honestly don't have a good name for this GM emulator, like Tiny Solitary Soldiers or Mythic. I guess MUNE is good enough.

Why play solo? How play solo?

Have you been kicked out of your weekly game for playing an edgy jerk? Has your DM canceled due to crippling anxiety, again? Has a small meteor with the word SCHEDULING hit your house?

And you still need to scratch that dungeon-roaming, character-building, monster-slaying itch? Then maybe solo D&D is the thing for you.

"Duwahhh? You can't play D&D by yourself, moron. That's not how TTRPGs work."

Why not?

"Because you need a DM..."

Ah, but you don't.

boardgame.name: Four Against Dungeons & Dragons
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

How to convert published D&D modules to use with Four Against Darkness.

boardgame.name: Perilous Intersections
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Perilous Intersections is a lightweight engine to power your solitaire roleplaying game adventures. It works by directing you to answer the Big Questions that brings a hero into conflict with a setting’s threat. It keeps some measure of surprise while the emergent plot provides resistance to the protagonist’s motivations. It works best with characters that have strong motivations and are action-driven. It can work in tandem with any existing RPG system, and is interactive, responding to the PC’s efforts to counter the main antagonist, making her choices matter.

boardgame.name: Doikayt
boardgame.description:
From the back of the book:

Doikayt is an anthology of tabletop roleplaying games by Jewish game designers about the ways we see our Judaism.

Judaism is built on a community with a shared tradition of dialogue and storytelling, so the idea to create games in conversation with Jewish history, culture, faith, and identity fits right in.

Inside, you will find 12 works chronicling many different aspects of Jewish life: conversations and wrestling matches with God, dinners with dybbuks and dinners at Chinese restaurants on Christmas, tales of golems, Motl, the cantor’s son, and the wise men of Chelm, delis, speakeasies, and synagogues.

Whether you are an RPG pro or you’ve never rolled a die before before, and whether you’re a rabbi or a gentile, you will find something in Doikayt to read, play, and maybe you’ll even learn something along the way.
boardgame.rpg: The Cantor's Son Is an Orphan Now and We Must Steal Him Lemons
If You Can't Take the Heat, Get Out of the Ring

boardgame.name: Same Bat Time, Same Bat Mitzvah
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

On the way to Rachel's Bat Mitzvah, a guest was bitten by a vampire bat and is transforming into a vampire during the formal reception.
boardgame.rpg: Same Bat Time, Same Bat Mitzvah

boardgame.name: Radlands
Senkiföldje
废墟之地
래드랜드
boardgame.description:
Radlands is a competitive, dueling card game about identifying fiercely powerful card synergies.

Act as the leader of your post apocalyptic group of survivors in a tooth-and-nail fight to protect your three camps from a vicious rival tribe. If all of them are destroyed, you lose the game.

The main resource in the game is water. You will spend it to play people and events, and to use the abilities of cards you already have on the table. People protect your camps and provide useful abilities, while events are powerful effects that take time to pay off.

Both players draw cards from the same deck. All cards can either be played to the table or discarded for quick “junk” effects. To win, you will need to manage your cards and water wisely.

boardgame.name: A New Horizon
boardgame.description:
From the game:

You are an Interplanetary Space Probe who has completed your primary mission, and are currently travelling through intergalactic space having escaped the solar system & galaxy long ago. Other players take on the roll of Mission Control, recording & analyzing your data.

boardgame.name: Kosmodraci
Space Dragons
boardgame.description:
Welcome, daring ones! Are you ready for a flight into the galaxy of the notorious space dragons? You will need to assemble your crew before take-off, but then what? Will you capture a dragon or patch up the ship before it blows up in your face? Activating shields may sound boring but doing so could boost the mood of your crew — and thus earn you those last few victory points!

Space Dragons is a trick-taking-ish game that plays over seven rounds. Each round, everyone plays a single card, and the highest card played wins the current space dragon (trick). That said, lower-value cards come with strong effects to help you during the game, while high-value cards might contain harmful effects. What's more while space dragons score you big points, some come with symbols that could ultimately cost you points during the final scoring.

The player with the most points after seven rounds is the most daring dragon hunter and the winner of the game.

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Magician's Market
boardgame.description:
Created for the 2020 Children's Game Print and Play Design Contest, winner of the Best Educational Game category.

Magician's Market is a Print and Play educational game for children and families that teaches colors and color mixing in a fun and exciting way.

You are magicians, trying to make potions to sell at the market. There are limited ingredients available. Rolling two colored dice determines what options you have available to draft each round. You can split or combine colors to make new ingredients, or buy a new recipe card to try making a different potion. The game ends when one player completes a certain number of potion cards (dependent on player count). The player with the highest combined potion values is the winner.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: A Most Fearful Sacrifice: The Three Days of Gettysburg
boardgame.description:
It's early on July 1st, 1863, and Union Brigadier General John Buford’s 1st Reserve Cavalry Division is deployed to the west of the town of Gettysburg battling unidentified Confederate infantry advancing on the town. All morning long, the men in gray have pressured the Union cavalry. Help finally arrives in the form of I Corps commander Major Gen. John Reynolds. He rides up to the Lutheran Seminary, where Buford is directing the battle from its cupola. Reynolds calls to Buford, "What goes, John?" The cavalryman simply points to the long lines of advancing Confederates and says, "The Devil's to pay!" Reynolds then asks, "Can you hold?", to which Buford responds, "I reckon I can." Reynolds ends the exchange with, “Let’s ride out and see all about it." And with that rather brief, mundane conversation began one of the most important and iconic military engagements in history – the Battle of Gettysburg.

A Most Fearful Sacrifice is an epic two-player wargame with over 15 square feet of playing area and 526 playing pieces depicting the fighting that occurred during all three days of this decisive clash. The game utilizes a new ACW operating system called the Black Swan system, which is closely related to the popular Blind Swords game system first introduced in the game The Devil’s To Pay! by Tiny Battle Publishing. This version of the system is specifically designed to handle larger-scale battles yet keep rules overhead low. Players can simulate huge encounters in a reasonable amount of playing time. This is accomplished in one way through the use of card draws rather than chit pulls. Also, players will trigger activations by Corps instead of by lower-level formations but they still have tactical decision-making choices by needing to determine which Divisions get activation priority. Though at a grander scale, this system maintains a tactical feel about it and still emphasizes the three “FOW’s” of war … the Fortunes of War, the Friction of War and the Fog of War. Players will be challenged to deal with a constantly developing battle situation, never quite sure of what the Gods of War will throw at them, and thus they must always be prepared to deal with historically realistic “black swan” events.

COMPONENTS:
1 – Full color rulebook
1 – Full color scenario Book with THIRTEEN scenarios. Nine use one of the two maps, four use both.
2 – 30x41" full color mounted Game Maps (60x41" together)
4 - Sheets of a total of 352 13/16” (that's big) counters
1 – 5/8” counter sheet (176 counters) for the admin markers
90 - Cards to activate corps, initiate planned events, trigger unplanned events and create fog of war.
2 – Player Aids
2 – large, 11" x 17" Command Displays
6 – Dice (2 red, 2 black, 2 white)

-description from publisher's website

boardgame.name: Centre Ouest Bretagne: Le Jeu
boardgame.description:
Centre Ouest Bretagne, Le Jeu is a local and user-friendly board game based on the principle of questions and answers.

Nearly 500 written questions and photos with also charades and riddles, 60 "junior" questions, which deal with subjects as varied as history or geography, heritage, local traditions, current events or famous people who have marked the Centre Ouest Bretagne region.

Each player places his pawn on his commune of residence or of his choice among the 108 of the region, from Mûr de Bretagne to Pleyben, Callac to Faouët via Carhaix, Rostrenen and Gourin.
You will travel through the territory and have to answer questions on different themes. If the answer is correct you can replay.
To be the winner, you will have to collect 5 "Site" cards by going to their respective box and answering the question correctly.

boardgame.name: Storm Chasers
boardgame.description:
Thick clouds billow on the horizon as you speed towards a rising storm. You are a freelance storm chaser, risking it all by placing yourself in the heart of the storm. Will your actions pay off or will your livelihood be swept away with the changing wind?

Storm Chasers is a hand management, tile manipulation game for 2-4 players. In Storm Chasers, players manipulate the weather across region tiles to maximize their film footage of Thunderstorms and tornadoes as they sweep through regions.

In a turn, a player can use cards in their hand to benefit themselves or to affect other players. They can move from one region tile to another to increase the number of regions they will view when a storm is activated. They can flip/rotate tiles to create longer storm fronts, maximizing their potential income, and change the type of storm to strategically meet their goals. Players can clear rubble left from previous tornadoes, and complete special assignments to earn additional income. A player's turn ends by activating a storm using a card from their hand. Income or loss of income due to damage are subsequently dealt to each player who is affected by the activated storm. But players should be careful not to get to sure of themselves. The competition is fierce, you never know when a competing storm chaser might surprise you by adding an unanticipated challenge.

After 4-6 rounds (depending on player count of 2-4 players) the player with the highest earned income value wins and is awarded the coveted "Eye of the Storm Award" for excellence in extreme weather videography.

—description from the publisher

SoniComi(ソニコミ,full title Communication with Sonico) is a computer game for Microsoft Windows released on November 25, 2011, developed by Nitroplus and published by Nitroplus and Enterbrain. As a visual novel game, the player takes the role of Sonico's cameraman. The game features events where the player is able to take gravure photographs of her. A PlayStation 3 adaptation with improved visuals, titled Motto! SoniComi(モット！ ソニコミ,full title More Communication with Sonico, was released on March 20, 2014. The PS3 version received a Famitsu score of 30/40. The game was released worldwide with English translation by JAST USA through Steam featuring dubbed voice by Jessica Nigri.

boardgame.name: SoniPro

As an idol-producing game, the player takes the role of Sonico's producer, who aims to train her to become an idol. The game was released on July 31, 2014.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Sonico%23SoniPro_%282014%2C_3DS%29 Super Sonico]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Fantasmas Locos
boardgame.description: Fantasmas Locos is a fun didactic game of deduction and coupling ideal for family life. The goal is to be the first to accommodate or stack their ghosts as indicated on the cards, the first to do so will be the winner.

boardgame.name: Surviving Quarantine
boardgame.description:
Surviving Quarantine, a fun and fast paced card game that brings humor, silliness and much needed insanity to our current situation. No pregame setup required, just deal and go!

Pass the time dodging a virus by......well......surviving really ridiculous viruses in our game with your family and friends.

The rules to the game are simple

It takes less than 5 minutes to learn to play and can be played in 10-20 minutes or longer if you want.

It's easy, you just try to avoid getting stuck with the virus cards, and if you don't you are out of the game.

If you have a Virus Card in your hand, during your turn you can play it and give it to any player by naming them......If they can't survive with the cards in their hand they are out......If than can survive somehow play restarts with them.

It is now there turn to play another card.

Attack other players, skip players, gang up on friends.....sometimes its a crazy mashup of surviving and knowing who to eliminate. The last person remaining is the winner.

There are many ways to survive with silly anti+dote card combinations or even more crazy vaccines.

The simplicity of the cards allows all ages to enjoy playing......and the game modes allow players to be more strategic with the game.

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Crimes in History: H. H. Holmes' Murder Castle
boardgame.description:
NOTE: The 2nd Story Expansion is not included. For the edition that came with expansion, see this entry.


You will travel back in time to 1893 to explore the twisted and unpredictable World's Fair Hotel. Race to collect evidence while battling through the absurdities of a chaotic, booby-trapped castle - all while dodging Holmes himself. In Crimes in History: H. H. Holmes' Murder Castle, you will explore rooms and collect evidence, while battling backstabbing overnight guests and evading Holmes in his thrilling house of horrors.

- The castle can be built differently each time using unique modular room tiles inspired by the original castle's blueprints.
- Trapdoors, greased chutes to the basement, brick walls, and seeping gas are just some of the booby traps you'll encounter as you travel throughout the castle.
- Because Holmes knows the layout of the castle and all of the castle's elaborate horrors, he can appear in any room with only a moment's notice.
- Draw from 79 event cards to gain a competitive advantage or to wreak havoc by sabotaging other players.

The winner is the first player to complete their evidence board and rack back to the Pharmacy!

Crimes in History: H. H. Holmes' Murder Castle is a competitive, medium to low weight, board game from Blueprint Gaming Concepts aimed at becoming one of the most versatile games on the market. The action drafting mechanic was inspired from Puerto Rico and San Juan to achieve player engagement with little down time in between turns. The event cards were inspired from Kings of Tokyo and include high amounts of player-to-player interaction. It's designed by Seth Cooper & Brandt Hoffman and features hand-drawn macabre illustrations by Holly Carden.

—description from the publisher
boardgame.boardgamecompilation: Crimes in History: H. H. Holmes' Murder Castle

boardgame.name: Make-a-Snake
SerpentinGiro
Tête-à-Queue
Весёлые змейки
boardgame.description:
The snakes need the sun to hunt and play. As they crawl from their hiding spaces early in the morning, they try to coil themselves so that their tail and their head are as close as possible. This way they are all snuggly and warm until they can soak up the sunshine.

Roll the die and add new parts to your snake! Bend it, coil it, extend it! At the end of the game, measure the distance between the snake's head and its tail. The player with the shortest distance takes the prize!

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: Volunteer Exile Programme
boardgame.description:
Congratulations Pitizens! You and your families have been volunteered to help humanity reclaim the Earth by establishing a settlement in No-Man’s-Land. You have been resettled from the Hub to a promising location and it is now your duty to follow the Committees’ directive to ensure this settlement prospers. Should you be successful in your endeavours, you will be granted an official ‘Thank You’ from the Committee. Best of luck!

In Volunteer Exile Programme players take the role of a Pitizen “volunteered” to manage a new settlement in the wasteland (consisting of a tableau) in order to try and earn the approval of the Committee.
Each turn they follow the Committee’s directive and attempt to perform as many actions as they can or wish. The directive will include actions such as:
• Draw a card into your hand,
• Play a card into your Settlement or the Directive,
• Discard a card from your Settlement or the Directive,
• Place a Raider,
• Eliminate a Raider,
• Move a Pitizen

Adding locations to the settlement will provide the player with bonuses for building and attacking. Attracting Pitizens to those locations provide additional bonuses to the settlement and to the wider wasteland. Attracting Raiders, however, removes all these bonuses and renders the location usefulness.

As players are adding to their settlement, the directive and moving Pitizens and Raiders, the availability and usefulness of the available actions will change as well as limits on useable Pitizens, Raiders and your carry over hand size.

The game continues in rounds until the Committee approval process is triggered when a player meets one of the end-game objectives set at the start of the game. The players then sum up their Action points, their Settlement value plus any Raiders they eliminated and the player with the highest score wins.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: Сражение. Военная игра
boardgame.description:
Battle is developed primarily for those people who are just starting to play wargames. It is based on the classic mechanics of wargames, which implies the presence of a playing field, divided into hexagons (with different types of terrain), game pieces reflecting combat units and the use of the so-called "Battle Table". Combat pieces-tokens move around the game map, spending their "movement points" - the more "movement points", the higher the speed of the unit. The main characteristic of the unit is its "combat strength". When troops enter a battle, then, depending on the "combat strength" of the units participating in it, a column is selected in the "Battle Table", on which players roll a die, which is used as a random number generator. The more the player has gathered strength in battle, the higher his chances of success.

In Battle players will control "armies" roughly corresponding to the troops of France, Russia, Germany and Great Britain in the second half of the 19th century - the opponents will have approximately more or less the same number of chips, However, each army has its own small characteristic national "flavor". Having become familiar with the game principles, the player can almost easily join the world of the historical tabletop wargame by turning to more complex game developments. In them, already dedicated to specific historical operations, it will be possible to lead "real" armies on historically accurate maps and try to achieve specific military goals that faced the real commanders of that era.

We are confident that as a result, our game will be interesting to everyone. For beginners, it’s like getting to know the first wargame, for sophisticated connoisseurs, it’s like a simple “tournament” balanced game that can be played quickly and easily in half an hour.

boardgame.name: Spooky Zestrea
boardgame.description: Zestrea print your own Halloween cards - spooky villagers guided by none other than Countess Betty and Lord Vlady! And just in case you might suspect the red stuff the Zestrea Halloween Boyars are sitting in is... blood... Well. You're right.

boardgame.name: Christmas Zestrea
boardgame.description: Print your own festive Zestrea! We prepared two Christmas themed Boyars for you, as well as a handfull of villagers dressed appropiately for the cold Romanian winters. Download the Christmas Zestrea files, cut your new cards and shuffle them with your existing Zestrea pack. Then tell us in earnest: what sort of clothing do your villagers prefer? Could thick winter clothes and the tasty smell of fresh Christmas cookies bring some extra luck for your winter weddings?

boardgame.name: Constructorres
Constructowers
boardgame.description:
You arrive home from school, enter your bedroom and... Julia and Paul have mixed all the pieces of your construction toys! However, you don't get upset. Instead, you join the party! There are so many ways of playing with all those pieces that you are sure to become the best builders in the whole world.

The goal of Constructowers is to build towers with cards while meeting the victory conditions of the different game modes.

Each card represents a floor of the tower you are building. To build a tower, cards are placed horizontally one next to the other in a column, so the sides that connect the cards match.

The towers you build have to meet 2 simple requierements:

1.- You can place a card above or below another card, depending on the game mode, if both cards share only one feature: building material, colour, or numbre of builders.
2.- The tower cannot have 3 consecutive floors (one on top of the other) that share a common feature.

The rulebook includes 3 different game modes.

-description from publisher
---

Llegas a casa del colegio, entras a tu habitación... ¡y Julia y Pablo han mezclado todas las piezas de tus juegos de construcción! Pero no te enfadas. En su lugar, ¡te unes a la fiesta! Hay tantas maneras de jugar con todas esas piezas que seguro que os convertís en los mejores constructores del mundo.

En Constructorres tu objetivo es construir torres con las cartas cumpliendo las condiciones de victoria de los diferentes modos de juego.

Constructorres es un juego de cartas. Cada carta representa una planta de la torre que vamos a construir. Para construir una torre, las cartas se colocan sobre la mesa en posición horizontal, unas junto a otras sin solaparse, haciendo coincidir los dibujos de las estructuras.

Las torres deben estar compuestas por varios tipos de construcciones, siguiendo estas 2 sencillas reglas:

1.-Puedes colocar una carta por encima o por debajo de otra, según el modo de juego, solo si coincide en una única característica con ésta: material, color o número de constructores.
2.- No puede hacer en la torre 3 cartas consecutivas (una sobre otra) que compartan la misma característica.

El reglamento incluye 3 modos de juego distintos.

boardgame.name: De Hartenkoningin
boardgame.description:
De Hartenkoningin (The Queen of Hearts) is an educational game with different maths games such as: addition, subtraction, grinding tables, surface area...

For Example:
You roll the three dice, look witch numbers you rolled. Afterwards you can choose in witch order you want to place them and then you can begin to add up to 100 or to subtract to 0. The player who gets to 100 or 0 first is the winner and wins a heart.

You choose for yourself or with your partner how you want to play this game.

There are 5 different game suggestions in the box. Other games can be downloaded from the Website.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Fallen Land: A Post Apocalyptic Board Game – 2nd Edition
boardgame.description:
Can you survive the aftermath of a nuclear and biological apocalypse? You are the leader of a faction of survivors competing against others for primacy. Assemble and equip your party, then set out to explore the wastes, claim resources, and actualize your agenda. Build and manage your town to protect your citizens and resources. Make and break treaties to navigate your way through the minefield of bribery, betrayal, and hubris of the other players.

Fallen Land is set in the ruinous aftermath of post-apocalyptic America and is a thematic board game for 1-6 players. Featuring sandbox-style game play, it combines the elements of a strategy board game with card building and role playing. Driven by macabre stories of a world gone mad, players must adapt to the ever-changing variables: the cards, stories, interactions, and other threats.

The second edition contains 757 cards compared to 540 in the first edition. The map now includes Canada and Mexico. It also contains expansions there were previously released separately - Fallen Land: A Journey into Darkness and Fallen Land: Outriders Trading Post.

-description from Kickstarter campaign page

boardgame.name: Code België
boardgame.description:
Code België (Code Belgium), is an educational game that helps children placing links between certain topics such as: important people, counties, rivers...

This game is an expansion of the original game codenames.

How to win the game? First of all, there are two teams (red and blue) with two leaders. On the table there are 25 cards set out. The leaders get to see a plan of the board(card) with their colors on it. The idea is that they link their colors by giving their team members a subject and the number of cards they have to guess.

If it's correct the leader places the color of his team on the card. If it's the card of the other team otherwise or if it's the bomb GAME OVER! The team who collects all his cards wins the game.
